content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.
title: Overview

title: Example Page 2

content:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.   Slides can be added in a few ways:
 Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.  Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: An example talk using Academic's Markdown slides feature.
title: Example Talk

content:
We’ve just entered week 0 (the induction week) of the semester here at Strathclyde, and I’ve been working more than usual trying to get good quality content online for the upcoming semester. The first two weeks’ worth of material is ready to go but there’s still 8 weeks left to do - I’m definitely not kidding myself that this semester is going to be straightforward.
This is going to be a reasonably short post, but i’m going to pin point some things that I’ve been doing over the past few weeks (some of which to help the students and some because I’m a perfectionist and can’t help myself).
Making materials for offline as well as online I’ve spent quite a lot of time making text resources because these transfer a bit easier to students with limited internet access, and some things are just easier to explain in text than in a video. I’ve used R-markdown to create this text content, because it allows me to create both html and pdf documents. I’ve structured my course so that each small topic comes with text online, generally with some exercises, and then has an associated downloadable pdf document that contains all of the information from the online activity.
Since the online text contains embedded exercises. I want to encourage the students to work through these. I’ve done this firstly by setting activity completion on the online materials but not on the downloadable materials; and secondly by restricting access to the downloadable materials until the online activity has been attempted (though if a student were unable to access the online activity I would provide access to the PDF document). The image below shows this for one of my activities in week 3.
  Consistent but not consistent I’ve tried to keep a fairly consistent weekly structure, with each week being visually similar to each other. Each week starts with a description of the learning objectives, followed by the materials and links to the live zoom sessions that are available each week (see below).
  The end of the week is also pretty consistent, and consists of the student reflection exercise discussed in one of my previous posts, as well as a weekly formative assessment in the form of either a quiz or a submission as shown below.
  During the week the students will work through a number of activities (I’m aiming for somewhere between 6 and 10). Those which contain a lot of information are contained in lessons and those which contain smaller (but no less important) points are contained within pages as demonstrated below.
  Within these activities I have tried to give a bit of variety. There are large elements of text and examples, which are interspersed with the occasional video where I think these are useful. These will also contain some sort of associated activity, be that an online programming activity, or an interactive H5P activity.
Overall the goal is to be consistent, though not so consistent that the students get bored.
Formatting Something that I’ve found myself enjoying quite a bit recently (and something that I’ve become a bit obsessive about) is formatting my materials nicely in MyPlace/Moodle. As I mentioned, I have been using R-markdown to produce HTML materials. I then use the output from that and copy it into the html editor within MyPlace - this is a bit hidden you need to click on the button for more options and then click on the button with </> shown on it.
One thing to not about this is that MyPlace has been created so that it is difficult to tamper with the themes, which means that it is hit-or-miss whether CSS will work. So I’ve had to do the formatting old school and use the style attribute of various HTML tags. I’ve saved the commonly used styles into a text document to make this a bit easier. I have styles for the following:
Code and output blocks
  blockquotes
  Information/Instruction Boxes
  I have also elected to change the default inline code colour for better accessibility.
Video Editing The final thing that I have been doing over the past few weeks is editing video. I’ve used zoom to record since it’s easy to get a video of both your face and a shared screen (be that slides or R). You can download a video that contains the shared screen alongside you speaking in a shared box, but I wasn’t particularly keen on that. My perfectionist tendencies kicked in here and I decided to try my hand at video editing, so that I could edit out my mistakes and edit together the video stream with my face in it and the video stream showing the shared screen. I’ve been using shotcut which is free and also relatively straightforward once you get the hang of it!
summary: We’ve just entered week 0 (the induction week) of the semester here at Strathclyde, and I’ve been working more than usual trying to get good quality content online for the upcoming semester.
title: It's Nearly Showtime

content:
In my last post I was thinking about how to get useful feedback from students by asking them to reflect on their learning once a week. This week I’m going to make a note on the mechanisms that I have put in place for students to get feedback on their own work.
The trickiest part of this for me has been trying to balance giving valuable and insightful feedback with maintaining a reasonable work load. Initially I had thought about asking students to submit an assignment each week that I would mark and give back to them, but it was pointed out by one of my colleagues that this would be a lot of work for me each week. I’ve tried to find something that falls somewhere in the middle of that balance, with a mixture of opportunities for automated feedback and more personalised feedback, as well as assessment being provided in multiple different forms.
 This article highlights the importance of allowing students space to reflect on their learning (which I’m doing), as well as providing various mechanisms for feedback. With that in mind I am proposing three main broad opportunities for feedback which I’ve described below. Each of these broad categories will have multiple activity types associated with them.
Weekly Q&A Forums & Email I’m planning on highlighting the forums and e-mail correspondence as opportunities for feedback this year. In my experience (and from speaking to some of my colleagues) students often think of feedback as being comments on a submitted piece of work, rather than responses to questions about their work.
I want these activites (although primarily the Q&A forums) to be seen as a mechanism for feedback as well as a study resource. I think that this may help to encourage the students to participate in the Q&A forum. I also want to encourage students to participate in these by answering each others questions, although I am less optimistic about this, based on my own experiences and those of my colleagues. I want to do some further reading on the subject, so watch this space for a blog post about using forums in online learning!
Activities Built into Content I have chosen to structure my material in a “see one do one” format, where the students will be given some information and will then be given a related task to do. The plan is that these will take the form of multiple choice quizzes, interactive elements powered by either Shiny or H5P or an interactive programming exercise. I currently use Datacamp Lite, but am hoping to transition to learnr tutorials…I’m just waiting on the neccesary infrastructure to be in place.
Within these elements, I want to make the feedback as valuable as possible. With that in mind it is key that the students get more than just whether their answer was right or wrong. the programming exercises allow you to build this in and direct the student to where they should consider changing their code, and allows me to incorporate feedback to encourage best practice in programming. Similarly it is straightforward to incorporate valuable feedback into multiple choice questions by correcting the reasoning that would lead to a student selecting each wrong answer. This is something that should be considered when designing the questions. This guide is pretty useful although constructing appropriate alternatives will be very context specific. H5P will be treated similarly to quizzes but will be more appealing and will add some more variety.
The Shiny applications are more challenging. With these, the idea is to build the feedback into the app responses, so that students can see the results of changing different parameters (and hopefully come to their own conclusions). This type of feedback is less “in your face”, but still very useful from an experiential learning point of view. These apps will be combined with other activities (e.g. programming exercises or discussion forums), though these will depend on the specific learning outcome that is associated with the activity.
I’m hoping that the feedback provided by all of these will be useful for sparking discussion, both during live sessions and within the Q&A forums.
Weekly Formative Assessment I’m also building a weekly assessment into the course. These won’t contribute to the final mark, since any changes to the assessment would need to be approved. Given the number of other changes that I’m making right now, I felt that going through the process to add these quizzes into the summative assessment would be too much. If these are successful then I may consider incorporating these into the course assessment in the future. Nevertheless, these are being planned to provide the students with additional feedback.
These assessments will be a mixture of quizzes and submissions. The quizzes would cover a week’s worth of materials and the submissions would be more involved and would cover more materials. I am aiming to make the submission examples similar to what might be seen in the mid-semester class test.
To help with giving feedback on the submissions, and in the interest of balancing workload and balance, I am currently looking into using rubrics a bit more. I have found this resource to be a really good guide so far. However, I am concerned that students may depend on having a rubric for assignments and will focus on this rather than understanding course content. I had a scan through this masters thesis which specifically focusses on the use of rubrics, and the literature seems to indicate that students like rubrics, and find them to be useful reflective tools. In addition to this it is suggested that the use of rubrics may help to relieve anxiety around teacher expectations of assignments. The more I have looked into using rubrics, the more I have realised that I need to learn about them. It seems that to be really effective the content of the rubrics has to be clearly and carefully planned…another future blog post perhaps! I think, if done properly, the short term effort will be worth it in the long run.
I am planning to use these formative assessments as a mechanism for feedback from the students to me. This will help me to assess the impact of the feedback exercises that are contained within activities earlier in the week. It will also, when combined with the activities embedded within the course material and the weekly reflections, give me an overview of the particular sticking points that students are coming across and will help me to address these in a useful way.
summary: In my last post I was thinking about how to get useful feedback from students by asking them to reflect on their learning once a week. This week I’m going to make a note on the mechanisms that I have put in place for students to get feedback on their own work.
title: Providing Valuable Feedback Online

content:
In my quest to provide a happy and helpful virtual classroom, I’ve recently been thinking a lot about feedback. I know that it is important for me to give students timely and useful feedback, and I’m building that in to various aspects of the class. I’ve recently been focussed on getting useful feedback from students.
I remember being an undergrad student and being asked at the end of a course to fill out a feedback form. I also remember finding that really annoying because I don’t get to see the benefit of any of that feedback. I wanted to make the effort to change things that students needed help with as the course progressed.
In my regression class last year I tried to collect more feedback, and asked students to fill in a short (four questions) questionnaire each week online. This wasn’t particularly successful - out of a class of around 200 I would get around 10 responses each week. However, I will say that the responses the I did get helped me to either make useful changes to the course material (e.g. adding video content or additional exercises where people highlighted issues) or to address why I was teaching things in a particular way.
I’m planning on still seeking weekly feedback, but I want this feedback to feel more student centred and I want to encourage students to reflect on how they feel about the course material. Student self-reflection has been indicated to help students see links in their studies, and take more responsibility for their learning (see here, here, here and here for a few examples). In the feedback, I want to focus on their own self-perception and their perceptions about the material rather than my performance, again trying to encourage the students to think about themselves.
Feedback Structure I’ve used the feedback module in moodle to collect responses. The responses will be anonymous, and the questions will be split into two sections; one part that I won’t look at in detail, another that I will look at in detail.
Part 1: Reflection on Effort and Understanding The first section, which I only plan on looking at over the class as a whole, asks the students to reflect on how much effort they have put in over the week and how they would rate their understanding. I’m hoping that the anonymity of the feedback module will encourage students to think honestly about this, which will therefore drive some level of student responsibility.
This first part consists of two multiple choice questions as shown below:
For the first question, it is relevant to note that I’ve designed the online materials to take somewhere between 6 and 8 hours, to keep it roughly in line with the 6 hours of contact time that they would get if they were taking the class face-to-face. The course is a 20 credit model spread over 10 weeks, so in theory the students would be expected to spend 20 hours per week on the class.
Since this course is aimed at MSc students, I’m not particularly concerned with individual time management, but would be interested to see how much time students spend on the materials overall. I may reconsider this when I modify this course for the second year undergraduates.
The second question is about the student reflecting on their own understanding. I’m asking students to use this as a reflection tool and this isn’t something that I’ll look into beyond the overall class level. I’m also considering adding my contact details to this question to encourage students who would place their understanding in the bottom three categories to contact me to arrange a meeting.
Part 2: Reflection on the Materials The second section will ask the students to reflect on the materials. There will be four questions (technically one is a sub-question) which allow the students to identify areas that they would like more information, areas that they felt were good and areas where they feel that some improvement could be made. These can be seen below:
I have tried to be careful with the wording of these questions, so that they take me out of the equation and put the ownership onto the students and what they want.
The first two questions are grouped together, and identify the concepts that students want more information about. This allows the students to identify areas where they need to focus their energy, and will also give me the opportunity to update materials where indicated by several students, or add information to the Q&A thread discussed in my previous post.
The next question asks students to identify activities that they have found most useful. This will encourage the students to think about what they have found more straightforward. By asking “Why?” I’m trying to encourage information about specifically what is good. I can then use this information to enrich other activities.
The final question asks students about what acitivites could be (should be?) improved. This will (I hope) help students to identify sticking points in the materials, and will help them to develop an understanding of how they learn best. I am trying to ellicit a bit more information by asking what they would change about the activity. This information, again will be valuable in helping me to identify things in each activity that I should by trying to avoid doing (and potentially replace these aspects with ideas from the previous question.)
Other Aspects of Feedback I already mentioned that I wasn’t particularly interested in using this to look at individual student performance or engagement. I’ve implemented some more automatic tools for this.
Student Performance Within the class I’m implementing a weekly quiz, which will cover all aspects of the materials from the week. I’m planning on using a mixture of question types, including open ended questions that I’ll mark and provide feedback on. Within questions that allow automated feedback I’ll provide detailed and specific feedback. I also want to encourage students to reach out if they are unsure of where they have gone wrong, or if their quiz mark is not what they had expected.
I’ll be able to use this to identify students who need additional support, so that I can try to encourage these students to ask for help.
Student Engagement It is always a bit more difficult to measure student engagement. How do you know if a student has actually watched a video or read some text? (spoiler: you don’t really.) Moodle contains the option to add a completion progress block to your class page (note that the completion block shown below is from a class with two weeks’ worth of activities).
  Each block corresponds to an activity, and will turn yellow for partially completed activities and green for completed activities.
I plan on using this, along with sensibly defined parameters for completion tracking in each activity to monitor student engagement (e.g. completed lesson or require a page to be viewed). Since I’m only trying to get a general overview of student completion this is sufficient.
summary: In my quest to provide a happy and helpful virtual classroom, I’ve recently been thinking a lot about feedback. I know that it is important for me to give students timely and useful feedback, and I’m building that in to various aspects of the class.
title: Getting Feedback from Student Reflection

content:
This is my first ever blog post. I decided to start a blog to give me a place to write down some thoughts on my teaching, particularly as we head into a unique year thanks to Covid!
I’m doing a PGCert in learning and teaching in higher education and have now taken 40 credits worth of classes. I’m really interested in the different teaching and learning pedagogies and wanted to try something totally new. Specifically I’m keen to implement blended learning in my classes, which isn’t currently the norm in my department.
If I’ve learned anything from my PGCert so far it’s that reflecting on teaching practice is really important. For context, I’ve taken over a class for the next academic year that has been in its current state since its creation (around 10 years ago I think) and I’m keen to make some fairly big changes to it. I’m definitely expecting some challenges to pop up along the way and wanted to have a dedicated space to keep track of the changes that I’ve made, along with my successes and failures. If anyone happens to come across this and have a bit of discussion around anything then that’s definitely a bonus!
Context The class that I’m focussing on (for now) is a 20 credit module that is delivered to students across three different MSc programmes. The students come from a wide range of backgrounds, so we have to assume no prior knowledge of programming or statistics. We assume a base level of high-school level maths.
The course itself combines an introduction to programming in R with introductory linear regression. Each of these topics sits within its own five week block. When delivered face-to-face there are 6 hours of live content per week split between lectures and practical sessions. In the first 5 weeks this is 2 hours of lectures and 4 hours of tutorials, for the second half the split of lectures to practicals is 4 hours to 2. The first thing that I am planning on doing is making this more consistent throughout the class, following the structure in the first half to make the focus of the class more practical. This change is also in line with the learning objective of the class, which focus more on the students being able to complete a full analysis (although of course the theoretical components will still be there!)
The class will be based in Strathclyde’s VLE, MyPlace, which is a wrapper for Moodle. So most (but not all) of the things that I discuss here will relate to Moodle as well as MyPlace.
General structure Within the course, each week will consist of two topics. The main learning materials that would be covered in lectures will be split into sensible small chunks, and each chunk will build on the previous chunk.
These chunks will have some reading or video content to give students information, and will be associated with at least one exercise or quiz for feedback to provide deeper understanding. The lesson module in Moodle is an underrated feature that lends itself well to this, and external tools can be easily embedded into individual pages within the lesson.
I’m hoping to pull materials from a variety of sources, including some that I’ve developed myself. I still have to work on this.
Tutorials The one thing that I have thought a lot about recently is how to deliver a typical computer lab or tutorial remotely. I think that, given that the students haven’t signed up to an online education, it is really important to still have synchronous sessions where students can interact with lecturers and tutors. Also important since it’s one of my favourite parts of teaching!
The issue with this is that not all students are comfortable with this, and some students may not even be able to access these session due to poor connectivity or limited technology. From my perspective then, it is important to think about a variety of options to provide tutorial support. I’ve decided on three main ways that I will provide tutorial support.
1. Live tutorial session
This will function in effectively the same way as a regular tutorial, but will use Zoom instead of being in a computer lab. I’m planning on having multiple tutors (the exact number will be dictated by the class size) and splitting the students into breakout groups to encourage collaboration. The students will be given the opportunity to self-select their group prior to the semester starting. I’ll then make any adjustments to produce properly sized groups, and get feedback from students who are unable to attend these live sessions.
Tutorial sheets will be available, along with the other materials, the week prior (i.e. week 2 materials will be made available at the beginning of week 1) as is typical in our fully online classes. The only thing I can’t decide on is whether it is best to have a really structured session or a completely unstractured session. I can see pros and cons of both. At the moment I’m leaning towards an unstructured session (as in a computer lab), where the tutors and I will drop in to tutorial groups almost in the same way as walking around a tutorial and talking to students.
Solutions for each tutorial sheet will be made available after the corresponding live session.
2. Live “Office Hours” session
The second option for tutorial support is to attend a live drop-in session. I’ll sit on an open Zoom session for an hour and answer any questions from students who drop in. The idea is that dropping in to ask a question will require less data (and less bandwidth) than a full live session, but still provides personal contact.
These sessions will be completely unstructured, and will require students to do the work and ask specific questions. The nice thing about this is that it allows screen sharing which makes it fairly straightforward to diagnose programming issues.
3. Discussion forum/email
The final way in which I will offer support is via a discussion forum. I haven’t had great success with these in the past, so I’m going to label these “Q&A” so that they have a definite purpose and students aren’t going to be put off by the word “discussion”.
If students still feel uncomfortable posting then I will answer questions via e-mail, and also add any relevant questions to the discussion forum with an answer. Similarly, if any common questions come up in the live tutorial or during the office hour session these will be added to the Q&A thread with an answer.
I’m anticipating that the forums will be populated by me for at least the first couple of weeks, but I’ll encourage students to look to these for answers and am hoping that seeing some questions that have already been asked will give students the confidence to post their own questions. These will then become a useful study tool, since they will essentially act as a “FAQ” for each week.
summary: This is my first ever blog post. I decided to start a blog to give me a place to write down some thoughts on my teaching, particularly as we head into a unique year thanks to Covid!
title: The Initial Step Towards a Blended Classroom

summary: Air pollution is a major public health concern, and large numbers of epidemiological studies have been conducted to quantify its impacts. One study design used to quantify these impacts is a spatial areal unit design, which estimates a population level association using data on air pollution concentrations and disease incidence that have been spatially aggregated to a set of non-overlapping areal units. A major criticism of this study design is that the specification of these areal units is arbitrary, and if one changed their boundaries then the aggregated data would change despite the locations of the disease cases and the air pollution surface remaining the same. This is known as the modifiable areal unit problem (MAUP), and this is the first paper to quantify its likely effects in air pollution and health studies. Additionally, we derive an aggregate model for these data directly from an idealised individual level risk model, and show that it provides better estimation than the commonly used ecological model. Our work is motivated by a new study of air pollution and health in Scotland, and we find consistent significant associations between air pollution and respiratory disease but not for circulatory disease.
title: Quantifying the impact of the modifiable areal unit problem when estimating the health effects of air pollution

summary: The oral administration of solid dosage forms is the commonest method to achieve systemic therapy and relies on the drug’s solubility in human intestinal fluid (HIF), a key factor that influences bioavailability and biopharmaceutical classification. However, HIF is difficult to obtain and is known to be variable, which has led to the development of a range of simulated intestinal fluid (SIF) systems to determine drug solubility in vitro. In this study we have applied a novel multidimensional approach to analyse and characterise HIF composition using a published data set in both fasted and fed states with a view to refining the existing SIF approaches. The data set provided 152 and 172 measurements of five variables (total bile salt, phospholipid, total free fatty acid, cholesterol and pH) in time-dependent HIF samples from 20 volunteers in the fasted and fed state, respectively. The variable data sets for both fasted state and fed state are complex, do not follow normal distributions but the amphiphilic variable concentrations are correlated. When plotted 2-dimensionally a generally ellipsoid shaped data cloud with a positive slope is revealed with boundaries that enclose published fasted or fed HIF compositions. The data cloud also encloses the majority of fasted state and fed state SIF recipes and illustrates that the structured nature of design of experiment (DoE) approaches does not optimally cover the variable space and may examine media compositions that are not biorelevant. A principal component analysis in either fasted or fed state in combination with fitting an ellipsoid shape to enclose the data results in 8 points that capture over 95% of the compositional variability of HIF. The variable’s average rate of concentration change in both fasted state and fed state over a short time scale (10 min) is zero and a Euclidean analysis highlights differences between the fasted and fed states and among individual volunteers. The results indicate that a 9-point DoE (8 + 1 central point) could be applied to investigate drug solubility in vitro and provide statistical solubility limits. In addition, a single point could provide a worst-case solubility measurement to define the lowest biopharmaceutical classification boundary or for use during drug development. This study has provided a novel description of HIF composition. The approach could be expanded in multiple ways by incorporation of further data sets to improve the statistical coverage or to cover specific patient groups (e.g., paediatric). Further development might also be possible to analyse information on the time dependent behaviour of HIF and to guide HIF sampling and analysis protocols.
title: Multidimensional analysis of human intestinal fluid composition

summary: The impact of poison information services on patient care in hospital, particularly decisions on whether to admit patients after initial attendance at an emergency department (ED), is unclear. In the United Kingdom, the vast majority of poisons information is provided by use of the online poisons information database, TOXBASE. We investigated the relationship between rates of hospital access to TOXBASE and rates of poisoning admissions from EDs in England and Wales to begin to address the interactions between use of poisons information and patient management as reflected by hospital activity. Data were obtained on attendances and admissions due to poisoning for individual National Health Service (NHS) Trusts in both England and Wales, together with data on the overall number of accesses to TOXBASE for drugs (pharmaceuticals and drugs of abuse), from 2008 to 2015. Rates of TOXBASE access and admissions per poisoning attendance in London were clearly different to the rest of England and Wales; London was therefore analyzed separately. Negative binomial generalized additive models were fit, incorporating an interaction effect, for accesses, attendances and admissions to check for variability according to hospital size. Additional models were then fit to assess whether there was any variation in association of overall TOXBASE use with rates of admission for 6 key drug subgroups: antidepressants, paracetamol, antipsychotics, opioids (including all medicines, but excluding heroin), heroin and non‐opioid drugs of abuse. Rates of TOXBASE use per Trust increased across the study period by 39.3% (95% confidence interval [CI] = 34.1%, 44.8%) in England and 76.9% (24.7%, 151.0%) in Wales, showing an increase in TOXBASE use which was substantially greater than the increase in poisoning attendances. Admission rates exhibited seasonality, with lower rates in January and February, increasing by 2.0% (1.0%, 3.1%) in England and 5.8% (5.5%, 5.9%) in Wales toward the middle of the year. The initial model fit indicated that the average proportion of poisoning patients admitted increased with both increasing attendances and increasing TOXBASE use (England and Wales overall, P
title: Use of the online poisons information database TOXBASE and admissions rates for poisoned patients from emergency departments in England and Wales during 2008 to 2015

Create slides in Markdown with Academic  Academic | Documentation
 Features  Efficiently write slides in Markdown 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides Supports speaker notes Mobile friendly slides   Controls  Next: Right Arrow or Space Previous: Left Arrow Start: Home Finish: End Overview: Esc Speaker notes: S Fullscreen: F Zoom: Alt + Click  PDF Export: E   Code Highlighting Inline code: variable
Code block:
porridge = "blueberry" if porridge == "blueberry": print("Eating...")   Math In-line math: $x + y = z$
Block math:
$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$
 Fragments Make content appear incrementally
{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}  Press Space to play!
One  Two  Three 
 A fragment can accept two optional parameters:
 class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS) weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears   Speaker Notes Add speaker notes to your presentation
{{% speaker_note %}} - Only the speaker can read these notes - Press `S` key to view {{% /speaker_note %}}  Press the S key to view the speaker notes!
 Only the speaker can read these notes Press S key to view    Themes  black: Black background, white text, blue links (default) white: White background, black text, blue links league: Gray background, white text, blue links beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links    night: Black background, thick white text, orange links serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links simple: White background, black text, blue links solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links   Custom Slide Customize the slide style and background
{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}} {{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}} {{< slide class="my-style" >}}   Custom CSS Example Let’s make headers navy colored.
Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:
.reveal section h1, .reveal section h2, .reveal section h3 { color: navy; }   Questions?  Ask
 Documentation
summary: An introduction to using Academic's Slides feature.
title: Slides

summary: The aim of this paper was to examine temporal trends in accesses to the UK’s National Poison Information Service’s TOXBASE database in Britain. Generalized additive models were used to examine trends in daily numbers of accesses to TOXBASE from British emergency departments between January 2008 and December 2015. Day-of-the-week, seasonality and long-term trends were analysed at national and regional levels (Wales, Scotland and the nine English Government Office Regions). The long-term trend in daily accesses increases from 2.8 (95% confidence interval (CI): 2.6–3.0) per user on 1 January 2008 to 4.6 (95% CI: 4.3–4.9) on 31 December 2015, with small but significant differences in population corrected accesses by region (p
title: Hospital usage of TOXBASE in Great Britain: Temporal trends in accesses 2008 to 2015
